title: Silver
data:
**Silver** is a [material](/wiki/Material "Material") for items that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*.

Silver is a type of [metal](/wiki/Metal "Metal") that cannot [corrode or rust](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion"), and hinders [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting") when worn as armor. Striking certain types of monsters with silver weapons will deal **silver damage** against them; any item made of silver is eligible for dealing damage to [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade").

Silver-hating monsters will not pick up silver [weapons](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") or [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor"), but will pick up other silver [items](/wiki/Item "Item"), e.g. silver [wands of speed monster](/wiki/Wand_of_speed_monster "Wand of speed monster").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 List of silver items](#List_of_silver_items)

- [2 Silver damage](#Silver_damage)
  - [2.1 You](#You)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [4.3 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [4.4 DynaHack](#DynaHack)

- [5 References](#References)

## List of silver items

The following items are made of silver:

- [silver sabers](/wiki/Silver_saber "Silver saber") (including [Grayswandir](/wiki/Grayswandir "Grayswandir") and [Werebane](/wiki/Werebane "Werebane"))
- [silver arrows](/wiki/Silver_arrow "Silver arrow")
- [silver daggers](/wiki/Silver_dagger "Silver dagger")
- [silver spears](/wiki/Silver_spear "Silver spear")
- [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") with the [randomized appearance](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") "silver wand"
- [rings](/wiki/Ring "Ring") with the randomized appearance "silver ring"
- [shields of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection")
- [The Bell of Opening](/wiki/The_Bell_of_Opening "The Bell of Opening")

[Silver dragon scales](/wiki/Silver_dragon_scales "Silver dragon scales") and [silver dragon scale mail](/wiki/Silver_dragon_scale_mail "Silver dragon scale mail") are made of [dragon hide](/wiki/Dragon_hide "Dragon hide"), not actual silver. [Spellbooks](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook") with the randomized appearance "silver spellbook" are made of [paper](/wiki/Paper "Paper").

Silver should not be confused with [mithril](/wiki/Mithril "Mithril"), a different material.

## Silver damage

Creatures vulnerable to silver are called **silver-hating** monsters. The following creatures are silver-hating:[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

- all [vampires](/wiki/Vampire_\(monster_class\) "Vampire (monster class)")
-   [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade")
- all [major demons](/wiki/Major_demon "Major demon") (i.e., all & except the [Riders](/wiki/Rider "Rider"), [mail daemons](/wiki/Mail_daemon "Mail daemon"), [djinn](/wiki/Djinn "Djinn"), and [sandestins](/wiki/Sandestin "Sandestin"))
- all [minor demons](/wiki/Minor_demon "Minor demon") except [tengu](/wiki/Tengu "Tengu")
- all [lycanthropes](/wiki/Lycanthrope "Lycanthrope")

Note that with the exception of lycanthropes, all of these are also classified as undead or demonic, and will also take an additional 1d4 from blessed weapons.

When one of these creatures is struck by a silver item, it will suffer an extra *d20* damage.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) This includes wielded non-weapons, or a silver ring worn while using [hand to hand combat](/wiki/Bare_hands "Bare hands") or [martial arts](/wiki/Martial_arts "Martial arts") without gloves.

[Silver arrows](/wiki/Silver_arrow "Silver arrow") deal silver damage only if shot from a [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow"). Wielding them, [twoweaponing](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon") two stacks, or throwing them without a [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow") does not deal silver damage.

Silver [weapons](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") are one of the few things that can harm [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade"). In some circumstances a makeshift silver weapon can be very valuable in [Orcus Town](/wiki/Orcus_Town "Orcus Town"). [Mirrors](/wiki/Mirror "Mirror") do one point of damage to [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade") but are not truly classified as silver. Also, the mirror will break after a single hit, so you're not likely to be able to kill the shade with it.

Unlike other damage bonuses, silver damage is not doubled by [Grayswandir](/wiki/Grayswandir "Grayswandir") or [Werebane](/wiki/Werebane "Werebane").

### You

[You](/wiki/You "You") are vulnerable to silver if you are [polymorphed](/wiki/Polyself "Polyself") into one of the monsters listed above or affected by [lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy").[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) In addition to receiving extra damage from silver weapons, this makes you unable to [wear](/wiki/Wear "Wear") or [wield](/wiki/Wield "Wield") silver items, and interacting with them will deal 1d10 damage, similarly to an [artifact blast](/wiki/Artifact_blast "Artifact blast").[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## Strategy

Because of the d20 damage bonus (averaging 10.5 damage), it may be a good idea to fight silver-haters even with a silver non-weapon, though then you cannot [twoweapon](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon") when doing this. However, enchanted non-silver weapons are likely to be better, especially if twoweaponing - at minimum, they may prove sufficient enough that switching to [wield](/wiki/Wield "Wield") a non-weapon is not worth the bother, except against [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade"). Remember to unwield your non-weapon once you are done fighting your silver-hating target, e.g. to avoid hitting a [disenchanter](/wiki/Disenchanter "Disenchanter") and draining the charges of that silver wand. If you plan to fight barehanded with a silver ring, take extra care not to accidentally strike a [cockatrice](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice").

If dealing with lycanthropy frequently, whether from being bitten by werecreatures in the early game or deliberately giving yourself lycanthropy as a form of drain resistance, you will need to keep track of which items are made of silver, particularly [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") and [rings](/wiki/Rings "Rings") - you can check your [discoveries](/wiki/Discoveries "Discoveries") by pressing [\\](/wiki/%5C "\\") or [\`](/wiki/%60 "`").

## Variants

Several variants implement an [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") system that allows metallic items to be made of silver. These variants also remove silver-specific weapons, since their mundane counterparts will have a silver-compatible material set; silver sabers are replaced with normal sabers.

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") introduces several new silver items:

- [silver long swords](/wiki/Silver_long_sword "Silver long sword")
- [silver maces](/wiki/Silver_mace "Silver mace")
- [silver short swords](/wiki/Silver_short_sword "Silver short sword")
- [silver bullets](/wiki/Firearm "Firearm")

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), various [wood](/wiki/Wood "Wood") and [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") objects can be made of silver, including armor and weapons of elvish and dwarvish make.

### UnNetHack

[UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") adds the chrome wand as a randomized appearance composesd of silver.

The limitation on wishes for magical items to the [wand of wishing](/wiki/Wand_of_wishing "Wand of wishing") makes silver items more valuable as wishes - the shield of reflection is non-magical in UnNetHack, so it can be obtained from an early wish e.g. via a [magic lamp](/wiki/Magic_lamp "Magic lamp") to protect yourself against wands.

### DynaHack

[DynaHack](/wiki/DynaHack "DynaHack") adds the silver short sword from SLASH'EM.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [hates\_silver](/wiki/Source:Mondata.c#hates_silver "Source:Mondata.c") in [mondata.c](/wiki/Source:Mondata.c "Source:Mondata.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [uhitm.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 558](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/uhitm.c#line558 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/uhitm.c")
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [uhitm.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 877](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/uhitm.c#line877 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/uhitm.c")
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [youprop.h in NetHack 3.6.1, line 368](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.1_Release/youprop.h#L368)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1904](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.1_Release/artifact.c#L1904)

[![This article may require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/b/b0/Nh343-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-343}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Silver

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Silver is a material for items that appears in NetHack.

Silver is a type of metal that cannot corrode or rust, and hinders spellcasting when worn as armor. Striking certain types of monsters with silver weapons will deal silver damage against them; any item made of silver is eligible for dealing damage to shades.

Silver-hating monsters will not pick up silver weapons or armor, but will pick up other silver items, e.g. silver wands of speed monster.

Contents

  • 1 List of silver items
  • 2 Silver damage
    • 2.1 You
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SLASH'EM
    • 4.2 GruntHack
    • 4.3 UnNetHack
    • 4.4 DynaHack
  • 5 References

List of silver items

The following items are made of silver:

  • silver sabers (including Grayswandir and Werebane)
  • silver arrows
  • silver daggers
  • silver spears
  • wands with the randomized appearance "silver wand"
  • rings with the randomized appearance "silver ring"
  • shields of reflection
  • The Bell of Opening

Silver dragon scales and silver dragon scale mail are made of dragon hide, not actual silver. Spellbooks with the randomized appearance "silver spellbook" are made of paper.

Silver should not be confused with mithril, a different material.

Silver damage

Creatures vulnerable to silver are called silver-hating monsters. The following creatures are silver-hating:[1]

  • all vampires
  •   shades
  • all major demons (i.e., all & except the Riders, mail daemons, djinn, and sandestins)
  • all minor demons except tengu
  • all lycanthropes

Note that with the exception of lycanthropes, all of these are also classified as undead or demonic, and will also take an additional 1d4 from blessed weapons.

When one of these creatures is struck by a silver item, it will suffer an extra d20 damage.[2][3] This includes wielded non-weapons, or a silver ring worn while using hand to hand combat or martial arts without gloves.

Silver arrows deal silver damage only if shot from a bow. Wielding them, twoweaponing two stacks, or throwing them without a bow does not deal silver damage.

Silver weapons are one of the few things that can harm shades. In some circumstances a makeshift silver weapon can be very valuable in Orcus Town. Mirrors do one point of damage to shades but are not truly classified as silver. Also, the mirror will break after a single hit, so you're not likely to be able to kill the shade with it.

Unlike other damage bonuses, silver damage is not doubled by Grayswandir or Werebane.

You

You are vulnerable to silver if you are polymorphed into one of the monsters listed above or affected by lycanthropy.[4] In addition to receiving extra damage from silver weapons, this makes you unable to wear or wield silver items, and interacting with them will deal 1d10 damage, similarly to an artifact blast.[5]

Strategy

Because of the d20 damage bonus (averaging 10.5 damage), it may be a good idea to fight silver-haters even with a silver non-weapon, though then you cannot twoweapon when doing this. However, enchanted non-silver weapons are likely to be better, especially if twoweaponing - at minimum, they may prove sufficient enough that switching to wield a non-weapon is not worth the bother, except against shades. Remember to unwield your non-weapon once you are done fighting your silver-hating target, e.g. to avoid hitting a disenchanter and draining the charges of that silver wand. If you plan to fight barehanded with a silver ring, take extra care not to accidentally strike a cockatrice.

If dealing with lycanthropy frequently, whether from being bitten by werecreatures in the early game or deliberately giving yourself lycanthropy as a form of drain resistance, you will need to keep track of which items are made of silver, particularly wands and rings - you can check your discoveries by pressing \ or `.

Variants

Several variants implement an object materials system that allows metallic items to be made of silver. These variants also remove silver-specific weapons, since their mundane counterparts will have a silver-compatible material set; silver sabers are replaced with normal sabers.

SLASH'EM

SLASH'EM introduces several new silver items:

  • silver long swords
  • silver maces
  • silver short swords
  • silver bullets

GruntHack

In GruntHack, various wood and iron objects can be made of silver, including armor and weapons of elvish and dwarvish make.

UnNetHack

UnNetHack adds the chrome wand as a randomized appearance composesd of silver.

The limitation on wishes for magical items to the wand of wishing makes silver items more valuable as wishes - the shield of reflection is non-magical in UnNetHack, so it can be obtained from an early wish e.g. via a magic lamp to protect yourself against wands.

DynaHack

DynaHack adds the silver short sword from SLASH'EM.

References

  1. ↑ hates_silver in mondata.c
  2. ↑ uhitm.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 558
  3. ↑ uhitm.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 877
  4. ↑ youprop.h in NetHack 3.6.1, line 368
  5. ↑ artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1904

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.4.3. Information on this page may be out of date.

Editors: After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-343}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.

rawPage:
'''Silver''' is a [[material]] for items that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''.

Silver is a type of [[metal]] that cannot [[erosion|corrode or rust]], and hinders [[spellcasting]] when worn as armor. Striking certain types of monsters with silver weapons will deal '''silver damage''' against them; any item made of silver is eligible for dealing damage to [[shade]]s.

Silver-hating monsters will not pick up silver [[weapon]]s or [[armor]], but will pick up other silver [[item]]s, e.g. silver [[wand of speed monster|wands of speed monster]].

==List of silver items==
The following items are made of silver:

* [[silver saber]]s (including [[Grayswandir]] and [[Werebane]])
* [[silver arrow]]s
* [[silver dagger]]s
* [[silver spear]]s
* [[wand]]s with the [[randomized appearance]] "silver wand"
* [[ring]]s with the randomized appearance "silver ring"
* [[shield of reflection|shields of reflection]]
* [[The Bell of Opening]]

[[Silver dragon scales]] and [[silver dragon scale mail]] are made of [[dragon hide]], not actual silver. [[Spellbook]]s with the randomized appearance "silver spellbook" are made of [[paper]].

Silver should not be confused with [[mithril]], a different material.

==Silver damage==
Creatures vulnerable to silver are called '''silver-hating''' monsters. The following creatures are silver-hating:<ref>{{function|mondata.c|hates_silver}}</ref>

* all {{monclasslink|V}}s
* {{monsymlink|shade}}s
* all [[major demon]]s (i.e., all {{white|&}} except the [[Rider]]s, [[mail daemon]]s, [[djinn]], and [[sandestin]]s)
* all [[minor demon]]s except [[tengu]]
* all [[lycanthrope]]s

Note that with the exception of lycanthropes, all of these are also classified as undead or demonic, and will also take an additional 1d4 from blessed weapons.

When one of these creatures is struck by a silver item, it will suffer an extra ''d20'' damage.{{refsrc|uhitm.c|558}}{{refsrc|uhitm.c|877}} This includes wielded non-weapons, or a silver ring worn while using [[bare hands|hand to hand combat]] or [[martial arts]] without gloves.

[[Silver arrow]]s deal silver damage only if shot from a [[bow]]. Wielding them, [[twoweapon]]ing two stacks, or throwing them without a [[bow]] does not deal silver damage.

Silver [[weapon]]s are one of the few things that can harm [[shade]]s. In some circumstances a makeshift silver weapon can be very valuable in [[Orcus Town]]. [[Mirror]]s do one point of damage to [[shade]]s but are not truly classified as silver. Also, the mirror will break after a single hit, so you're not likely to be able to kill the shade with it.

Unlike other damage bonuses, silver damage is not doubled by [[Grayswandir]] or [[Werebane]].

===You===
[[You]] are vulnerable to silver if you are [[polyself|polymorphed]] into one of the monsters listed above or affected by [[lycanthropy]].{{refsrc|youprop.h|368|nethack=3.6.1}} In addition to receiving extra damage from silver weapons, this makes you unable to [[wear]] or [[wield]] silver items, and interacting with them will deal 1d10 damage, similarly to an [[artifact blast]].{{refsrc|artifact.c|1904|nethack=3.6.1}}

==Strategy==
Because of the d20 damage bonus (averaging 10.5 damage), it may be a good idea to fight silver-haters even with a silver non-weapon, though then you cannot [[twoweapon]] when doing this. However, enchanted non-silver weapons are likely to be better, especially if twoweaponing - at minimum, they may prove sufficient enough that switching to [[wield]] a non-weapon is not worth the bother, except against [[shade]]s. Remember to unwield your non-weapon once you are done fighting your silver-hating target, e.g. to avoid hitting a [[disenchanter]] and draining the charges of that silver wand. If you plan to fight barehanded with a silver ring, take extra care not to accidentally strike a [[cockatrice]].

If dealing with lycanthropy frequently, whether from being bitten by werecreatures in the early game or deliberately giving yourself lycanthropy as a form of drain resistance, you will need to keep track of which items are made of silver, particularly [[wand]]s and [[rings]] - you can check your [[discoveries]] by pressing {{kbd|\}} or {{kbd|`}}.

==Variants==
Several variants implement an [[object materials]] system that allows metallic items to be made of silver. These variants also remove silver-specific weapons, since their mundane counterparts will have a silver-compatible material set; silver sabers are replaced with normal sabers.

===SLASH'EM===
[[SLASH'EM]] introduces several new silver items:

*[[silver long sword]]s
*[[silver mace]]s
*[[silver short sword]]s
*[[Firearm|silver bullets]]

===GruntHack===
In [[GruntHack]], various [[wood]] and [[iron]] objects can be made of silver, including armor and weapons of elvish and dwarvish make.

===UnNetHack===
[[UnNetHack]] adds the chrome wand as a randomized appearance composesd of silver.

The limitation on wishes for magical items to the [[wand of wishing]] makes silver items more valuable as wishes - the shield of reflection is non-magical in UnNetHack, so it can be obtained from an early wish e.g. via a [[magic lamp]] to protect yourself against wands.

===DynaHack===
[[DynaHack]] adds the silver short sword from SLASH'EM.
